Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Identifying the Substrate Proteins of Nedd4 Family of E3 Ubiquitin Ligase by Orthogonal Ubiquitin Transfer (OUT)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The CAREER award from the Chemistry of Life Processes Program (CLP) will support work by Professor Jun Yin at the University of Chicago to elucidate the mechanism of ubiquitin signaled protein degradation in the cell. Professor Yin will develop new chemical methods to engineer protein ubiquitination enzymes and use the engineered enzymes as tools to map the signal transduction pathways in the cell that regulate the life span of proteins. Ubiquitin is a small protein of 76 residues. It is attached to aged, unused or damaged proteins in the cell by a class of enzymes known as E3 ubiquitin ligase. Cellular proteins attached with ubiquitin are degraded by the 26S proteasome. Besides its housekeeping role, ubiquitin also serves as a signal to control the biological activities and subcellular locations of the proteins it is attached to. Quite often defects of protein ubiquitination are implicated in cancer, virus infection and neurodegenerative disorders. A major bottleneck in investigating protein ubiquitination in cell biology is that there is not a good method to identify the substrate proteins of E3 enzymes in the cell. Because of this, the biological functions of E3 enzymes are unclear and the cause of disease by defective E3s is hard to study. With the support of this CAREER award, Professor Yin will engineer the E3 enzymes so that each engineered E3 will attach unique chemical labels to their substrate proteins. In this way a E3 enzyme can be paired with its ubiquitination targets in the cell and the signal transduction networks that regulate protein degradation can be elucidated. In this work, E3 enzyme Nedd4-1, a key inducer of cancer, will be engineered in ordered to profile its substrate specificity. By associating E3 enzymes and their substrate proteins, this project will provide a general platform to define the biological function of the E3 enzymes, to elucidate the pathological connection of E3 with various diseases and to identify specific E3 enzymes as therapeutic targets for drug development.
The CAREER award will also support Professor Yin to train undergraduate and graduate students to use protein engineering in biological research. It will sponsor a freely accessible online database with a comprehensive collection of methods and applications of protein engineering. Furthermore it will provide an opportunity for the teachers and students from the local high schools in south side Chicago to visit Professor Yin's lab and get hands-on experience of modern research in chemistry and molecular biology. Overall Professor Yin will establish an integrated research and educational program to train future scientists at the interface of chemistry and biology and to nurture the interests of K-12 students in science at the early stage of their learning career.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The pyramidal organization of E1, E2 and E3 enzymes for ubiquitin (UB) transfer constitutes a major division of signal transduction networks in the cell. The 2 E1s at the top of the pyramid activate UB and load it on ~40 E2s. UB is then carried by E2 down the pyramid to >600 E3s which recruit a dynamic pool of substrate proteins for UB conjugation based on the demands of cell biology. The collaborative actions of E2 and E3 can extend a single UB on the modified proteins into a UB chain stitched together by linking the C-terminus of one UB and one of the 7 Lys residue or the N-terminal Met of another UB. The linkage types of UB chains are read as barcodes with rich information about the modified proteins such as the timing of proteasomal or non-proteasomal degradation, subcellular addresses, folding status, partnerships with other proteins, and cross-talks with other signals mediated by acetylation, glycosylation, and phosphorylation, etc. Virtually all key cellular processes including cell cycle, apoptosis, and intercellular communication rely on the correct inscription and interpretation of the UB code. The origins of many diseases including cancer, neurodegeneration, and inflammation can be traced back to the mis-assembly of the UB code. However, often when the malfunction of an E3 or aberrant ubiquitination of a cellular target is identified in a disease, the downstream targets of the defective E3 or the upstream E3s regulating the aberrant target are not known. The missing link between the E3s and their cellular targets is a serious hurdle to elucidate the molecular mechanisms of E3-mediated regulation of cell biology.

 Our goal for the NSF Career grant was to develop a proteomic platform named as “orthogonal UB transfer” (OUT) to identify the direct substrates of E3s. Our approach is to construct a UB transfer cascade composed of engineered E1, E2 and E3 that would exclusively transfer an affinity-tagged UB mutant (xUB) to the direct substrates of a specific E3 in the cell. We have successfully engineered the OUT cascade with HECT E3s E6AP and Rsp5, and U-box E3s E4B and CHIP. We expressed the engineered cascades and xUB in the HEK293 cells, and identified xUB-conjugated proteins by proteomics to generate a substrate profile of E6AP, E4B and CHIP. We also verified in vitro and in the cell that representative members of the identified proteins are indeed the substrates of the corresponding E3s. We have thus established OUT as an accurate and efficient platform in profiling E3 substrates to elucidate their roles in cell signaling.

The NSF Career grant also supported us to establish an educational program that integrates research on ubiquitin signaling with classroom teaching to promote science education among high school, undergraduate, and graduate students. I designed a program to train future scientists to conduct multidisciplinary research at the interface of chemistry and biology.  Coupling to our research on ubiquitin, we applied protein engineering methods to elucidate the fundamental mechanisms of cell biology. In the classroom, I developed a new Chemical Biology courses to teach the latest discovery in life science based on methods breaking the traditional boundaries between chemistry and biology. The NSF Career grant also supported my effort to expand educational activities beyond the university boundary. I participated in a Bio-Bus program to extend research opportunities to high schools in the low-income communities in Atlanta. I also hosted students from K-12 institutions to teach them basic research skills in my lab at the University of Chicago and later the Georgia State University.
